posts.name: tyler hedge
posts.cooked:
Falcon 500s can absolute drive a certain velocity, im not sure exactly what TalonFX object you are using so i cant help with specifics, but its something that they can do.

As far as how, you need to have a PIDF loop running on the motor you want to control to a velocity. And than you need to convert from units of m/s to falcon native units/100 ms.

If you need more specifics let me know!

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
rohanMoment:

Also, how do I convert from m/s to Falcon Native Units / 100ms?

Math.  You’re going to need your gearbox ratio as well as the wheel size in order to do that.  The integrated encoder is 2048 counts/rev.

posts.name: tyler hedge
posts.cooked:
I’m in class right now, but I’ll try and get you a link to the spreadsheet my team uses to compute P and F gains for the drivetrain. The PID controller objects you have on the path following are the same concept but they do different things. PID loops in simple terms use feedback to correct for error. The ones on the path controller look at how far away you are from where you should be in the path, than tell the motors to go faster or slower to compensate. The PID loop you need to run on the motors tells them how to react to velocity error. Motors have no real concept of velocity, just how much power to use, so the PID loop kind off act as a translator of sorts.

As far as the unit conversions, you need to convert from linear speed to 2048 ticks per revolution per 100ms on your falcon. I can write out the full conversion once im out of class.

posts.name: Rohan

posts.cooked: the Falcon500 integrated encoder has 2048 ticks per revolution.

posts.name: Rohan

posts.name: tyler hedge
posts.cooked:
heres a calculator you can use to compute the P and F gains for your drivetrain, these should be all you need for good control.

The math behind a PIDF loop is pretty simple if you’ve had calculus 1.

you have 4 gains: kF, kP, kI, and kD. you have a target velocity: v. you have an error: e such that e = v - current velocity.

your motor output is

(v * kF) + (e * kP) + (integral of e * kI) + (d/dx e * kD)

what this means in laymans terms:

F stands for feedforward. you cant definitively know what % output you require to reach a certain velocity, but you can make a good guess as a starting point, thats what feedforward is. It relates a desired velocity, to your best guess of the required % output.

P stands for proportional, because its output is proportional to your error. Basically its how much % output do you want to add to compensate for error.

I stands for integral. It handles past error. It is proportional to the integral of your error (which for velocity is your positional error) it is seldom used because it can build up over time and cause poor behavior, but it can be used to handle cases when a system has a very small amount of error over a long period of time.

D stands for derivative. It handles future error. It is proportional to the derivative of your error (which for velocity is your acceleration error) it is useful for preventing oscillation from your P gain, and counters rapid drops in velocity.

in a drive train F and P is sufficient for quality control.

posts.name: tyler hedge
posts.cooked:
HB_PID-JVN-DesignCalc.20191207.xlsx (854.5 KB)

Hmm not sure why the link is having issues… I attached the file to this reply, see if that works.

For the most part, you’ve got it, the only thing is, people have already done the math for you.

What you’re proposing would absolutely work, except when you actually reference the motor you would use ControlMode.PercentOut, because, in this case, you still haven’t told the motor what velocity is, instead you are doing all the heavy lifting and the computation for the motor.

Luckily, people have already written all the math for us. You can call the WPI_TalonFX.configKF (and P) methods to configure those parameters on the motor. Then when you command the motor in ControlMode.Velocity (with an argument in ticks/100 ms) the built-in motor controller will run the closed loop you have given it at 1khz (20 times faster than your robot code) to get the robot to the desired speed.

This is an aside to the rest of this post, but closed-loop control is a very useful technique for many things. I would recommend using ControlMode.velocity in teleop in addition to auto, because it makes the driving more consistent. (e.g the driver doesn’t have push the stick further to go the same speed as the battery voltage falls, instead the P gain will apply more power). Also for linear motion you can use the Falcons ControlMode.MotionMagic, which automatically generates trapezoidal motion profiles when you define an acceleration and cruise velocity which makes smooth motion super easy. If you have an arm or an elevator this I would absolutely recommend looking into this.

posts.name: tyler hedge
posts.cooked: Also, this calculator was written for a tank drive, and by people smarter than I am. (namely the original was created by @anon91315253 , and the one I linked was modified by @jaustinpage ) I’m not sure how the math changes with a mecanum drivetrain, hopefully though, that calculator will get you a good starting point. If you end up needing to tune it, I would use Phoenix tuner to ensure that it’s actually reaching its target velocity. If it isn’t then you may need to increase the P gain. If it oscillates, that means that P is too high, and it’s overshooting its setpoint back and forth.

posts.name: Rohan
posts.cooked:
Thank you so much for the detailed explanation! A few questions though:

Do the PIDController objects in the Autonomous Command Constructor play into all of this? If so, how?

Also, if you are able to guess, in which range(s) would the kF and kP values fall?

(By the way, the link is working; I realized that it was an Excel File so I just imported it into Google Sheets)

posts.name: tyler hedge
posts.cooked:
The PID Controllers in the auton command is the exact concept applied to a different thing. The ones in the motor help you stay at a certain velocity, whereas the ones in the command help keep you on track. Let’s say your robot drags along the ground and ends up 1 foot behind where you should be at that point in the path. The PID controller in the command will, in turn, tell the motors to go to a higher velocity to catch up. The motors will then use their PID controllers to get to the commanded velocity.

as far as the kP and kF values, not sure exactly, it’s been a little while. But the answer is small, probably in the hundredths space. The nice thing about a drive train is that it’s pretty hard to break because it’s continuous, so it’s pretty safe to just guess and check.
